Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2012 05:49AM holdontohope wrote: So sorry Kita.  This must be so distressing.  Praying that you hear soon about the trial and that it works!
Posts.Title: tumors showing, chemo not working, turning 25 kita barsco1963

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 05:52AM holdontohope wrote: Bon, thanks for the info.  We have not seen much effects from this storm, except for the rain.  And even that is not so bad.  There is a bit of light snow falling right now.  The new generator is still in its box.  Hopefully, we won't have to use it. We share a well with our neighbors.  The well is on their property and the electricity for the pump is from their house.  We have been talking about the best way to handle this in a power outage.  We may end up sharing the cost of a generator just to run the well pump. We have plenty of gas stored in our shed.  The thing I can't figure out is how to run a generator when it is raining.  The instructions say keep it outside (of course) away from doors and windows and don't run it in a garage or shed.  Then how are you supposed to keep it dry???  I will be doing more research after this storm is over. Still praying for those who have been so severely impacted by Sandy.
Posts.Title: OT...Can you say freezing! LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2012 06:38AM holdontohope wrote: Checking in from the western side of Virginia.  Only rain so far; haven't felt much wind.  We are forecast to get 2-6" of rain and wind gusts of up to 60 mph this evening and into tomorrow.  We bought a generator and we have a wood stove.  The worst is losing running water.  Because we have a well, when the power goes out we have no water.  So we've been filling up 5-gallon buckets. We are expecting the power to go out--who knows how long.  But that is nothing compared to what those closer to the coast are getting hit with.  Stay safe everyone!
Posts.Title: OT...Can you say freezing! LuAnnH

Thanks for your good wishes; you too K-Lo. I will be switching to a new oncologist in about two weeks and that is making me feel more hopeful.

Elizabeth, I'm tired alot and definitely have less of an appetite.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2012 04:07AM holdontohope wrote: Ann, I got Halaven by push.  Got terrible heartburn; took Prilosec for that (like Alesta said--the kind where you think "Am I having a heart attack?").   When I got my first Halaven treatment, it was 100% dosage.  That was too much for me to handle.  WBC tanked; got dehydrated because I couldn't eat or drink--everything tasted bad and I got a thrush like SE in my mouth; and fever.  They reduced my dose to 80%; it still worked and the side effects were more manageable. Really hoping this works for you, Ann!

Posts.Title: Halaven, here I come CoolBreeze CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 10:01AM holdontohope wrote: Ann, I agree with soleil.  Halaven can work very well, but the side effects can be pretty bad, especially if you get the full dose.  I got the 100% dose the first time and the side effects were so bad, they dropped the dose to 80%.  I still needed neupogen and neulasta shots to get my treatments on time.  Not trying to discourage you, but maybe ablation or a different chemo might be an option.
Posts.Title: Halaven, here I come CoolBreeze CoolBreeze

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2012 01:47PM holdontohope wrote: You're right, K-Lo, we all don't have the same response to the different chemos.  I was thinking that Ann posted somewhere that she couldn't do the neulasta or neupogen shots, and that was the only way I could continue on Halaven, even at a reduced dose. Maybe Ann will have no problem with that--hope so!
